Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 45073  
Research and Development Technical Assistance (RDTA) 
December 2011 
 
 
 
Innovative Financing for Agriculture  
and Food Value Chains 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ADF  –  Asian Development Fund 
  AFVC  –  agriculture and food value chain 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  MDB    –  multilateral development bank 
  SMAEs  –  small and medium-sized agro-enterprises 
  TA  –  technical assistance

Sector (subsector)  –  Agriculture  and  natural  resources  (agricultural  production  and

Vice-President  B. N. Lohani, Knowledge Management and Sustainable Development 
Director General  X. Yao, Regional and Sustainable Development Department (RSDD) 
Team leader  L. Adriano, Advisor, concurrently Practice Leader (Agriculture, Rural

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Financial  sector  development  through  more  diversified  and  market-driven  financial 
products and services, with broad-based outreach in rural areas, is one of the strategic core 
areas  of  operation  for  inclusive  and  balanced  growth  under  Strategy  2020  of  the  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB).1 The  ADB  Operational  Plan  for  Food  Security  in  Asia  and  the 
Pacific2 and the Financial Sector Operational Plan3 prioritize investments, policy reforms, and 
capacity building to enhance the efforts of developing member countries (DMCs) to expand 
financial access for the traditionally underserved such as smallholder farms and small and 
medium-sized  agro-enterprises  (SMAEs).  Consultations  with  ADB  regional  operations  and 
private  sector  departments  have  confirmed  that  access  to  finance  for  the  development  of 
agriculture and food value chains (AFVCs) is a widespread binding constraint. This regional 
research and development technical assistance (TA) is about bridging the knowledge gaps that 
impede access to AFVC financing for smallholder farms and SMAEs.4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  AFVCs are emerging in Asian DMCs, albeit at different paces. Important drivers of AFVC 
development  include  urbanization,  income  growth,  changing  dietary  preferences,  increased 
female labor force participation, and access to better household technologies and information 
about food.5 A typology of AFVCs in terms of the nature and degree of vertical integration 
between and among the different actors in the chain includes (i) traditional AFVCs, which are 
typified  by  their  weak  connection  and  involvement  of  many  players  in  the  production, 
processing, marketing, and distribution activities, resulting in numerous risks, huge transactions 
costs, and low financing; (ii) transitional AFVCs, which have less player intermediation at the 
postharvest to market levels but have limited options for risk mitigation and financing; and 
(iii) modern AFVCs, which are characterized by stronger integration of the supply chain players 
that  ensure  economies  of  scale  and  scope  through  seamless  logistics,  and  technical  and 
financial support,  as well as wide market outlets.6 The focus of many AFVC studies has been 
on understanding the traditional and modern AFVCs. There is very limited knowledge of the 
transitional  or  the  “middle  AFVCs,”  which  is  nonetheless  important  to  examine  as  these 
essentially  serve  as  the  transition  ladder  from  traditional  to  modern  types  of  AFVCs. 
Understanding  the  development  impacts  of  the  AFVCs’  structural  transformations  on 
smallholder farms and SMAEs would be a significant value addition to studying their contribution 
to inclusive growth.  
 
3.  One of the major drivers that facilitate the transformation of AFVCs is the availability of 
and access to innovative financing. The types of value chain financing vary, depending on 
whether the flow of financing is from within the chain segments, or between and among chain

2   
actors,7 or obtained from outside the chain, which is related either directly or indirectly to linkage 
arrangements in the chain.8 Although the array of financing instruments used in these various 
types of AFVC financing is not new, the emerging providers of finance do not mainly come from 
formal  financial  institutions.  The  innovative  application  of  various  institutional,  contractual, 
managerial, and technological arrangements is also essential to adapt to the needs of AFVCs 
for  stronger  and  more  demand-driven  value  chain  coordination.  Whether  these  novel 
arrangements respond to the effective demand for AFVC financing of smallholder farms and 
SMAEs, and meet their investment threshold needs, will need to be examined.  
 
4.  One of the major bottlenecks to promoting AFVC financing for smallholder farms and 
SMAEs is the poor business climate caused by multiple levels of government interventions that 
discourage or undermine private sector investments in AFVCs. At the macro level, monetary, 
tax,  trade  policies,  and  regulatory  measures  inhibit  the  development  of  different  financial 
instruments and arrangements such as the use of warehouse receipts and lease arrangements. 
Restrictive marketing policies, commodity pricing controls, and poor quality standard regulations 
may also disadvantage the competitiveness of AFVCs and the terms of trade against financing 
of AFVCs, and inhibit the diversification of activities within the chain. At the sector levels, some 
regulatory measures restrict the participation of private sector intermediaries such as insurance 
firms and collateral managers. Weak measures for transparent, accountable, and enforceable 
contracts also prevent the outreach and availability of AFVC financing instruments. At the micro 
level, constraints to the capacity development of grassroots organizations such as farmers’ 
groups,  chambers  of  SMAEs,  and  community-based  microfinance  institutions  impede  the 
growth  of  inclusive  and  sustainable  AFVC  financing.  Poor  local  public  governance  and 
inadequate measures for the fair treatment of all players disproportionately result in the weak 
bargaining leverage of smallholder farmers and SMAEs, and create mistrust between players.  
 
5.  Creative solutions for inclusive and sustainable AFVC financing are emerging regionally, 
but the majority of these experiences, such as contract farming, use of warehouse receipts, 
forward contracts, and marketing company credit, have difficulties for start-up, replication, or 
scaling up, especially in the low-income DMCs (Asian Development Fund [ADF] countries). A 
large  lacuna  has  been  on  technical  support  for  facilitating  the  development  of  innovative 
approaches that link smallholder farms and SMAEs to potential AFVC financial providers and 
markets. Specific technical support financing gaps are often in the areas that address critical but 
low-cost, quick-disbursing expenses with high impact. These include (i) soft infrastructure build-
up  (e.g., entrepreneurship  training,  governance  tool  kits,  and  conduct  of  market  studies); 
(ii) information  infrastructure  that  needs  opportunities  for  showcasing  or  trial  testing 
(e.g., software that facilitates traceability, and social networking among entrepreneurs in the 
chain);  (iii) institutional  arrangements  that  address  specific  risks  (e.g.,  poor  food  safety 
standards); (iv) contractual or partnership agreements that need to be fine-tuned or tested 
(e.g., local government–private partnerships); (v) a start-up fund for equipment or technology 
(e.g., environment-friendly  packaging,  small  technology  for  grading  and  assembling);  and 
(vi) database  or  knowledge  management  for  improving  logistics  and  information  sharing. 
Providing for these technical support needs may encourage the development of AFVC financing

3 
options for smallholder farms and SMAEs, and promote the transition from the traditional to 
transitional and modern AFVCs. 
 
6.  Bridging the knowledge gaps between and across value chain actors and providers of 
AFVC financing is also important to broaden the outreach and availability of AFVC financing to 
smallholder  farms  and  SMAEs  in  ADF  countries.  Utilization  of  technological  advances  in 
information and communication technology and the different social network arrangements may 
be needed to reduce the knowledge gaps, and improve the take-up of innovations in AFVC 
financing for DMCs.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
7.  This  TA  addresses  the  knowledge  gaps  on  AFVC  financing,  with  the  end-view  of 
expanding the outreach of AFVC financing to smallholder farms and SMAEs, especially in the 
ADF countries. These DMCs are generally dependent on traditional AFVCs, and have identified 
weak access to credit by smallholder farms and SMAEs as major impediments for improved 
productivity, market connectivity, and resilience to natural and economic shocks. Stronger and 
coordinated AFVCs with a wider range of AFVC financing options will stimulate inclusive growth 
in these economies. Appendix 1 provides the design and monitoring framework of the TA.  
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The  expected  impact  by  2016  will  be  the  improved  access  to  AFVC  financing  for 
smallholder farms and SMAEs in participating low-income DMCs. To achieve this impact, the 
TA’s outcome will be the development of innovative AFVC financing framework.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The TA  will  have  three  outputs: (i)  submission  of  a  policy  report for inclusive  and 
sustainable AFVC financing to the Governments of Bangladesh and Cambodia, (ii) development 
of innovative AFVC finance business models for smallholder farms and SMAEs in participating 
low  income  DMCs  for  deliberation  by  AFVC  financial  providers,  and  (iii)  application  of  a 
knowledge platform on innovative AFVC financing by selected DMCs.  
 
10.  For output 1, a comprehensive literature review  will be conducted on the financing 
modalities  and  products  for  AFVCs,  and  the  major  policy  and  institutional  bottlenecks  to 
ensuring inclusive and sustainable AFVC financing and growth in Asia. A stacked survey and 
evidence-based case studies for different AFVC typologies and AFVC financing types will also 
be  conducted.  Based  on  demand  and  supply  analysis  for  AFVC  financing,  policies  and 
institutional barriers will be studied in terms of inclusiveness, sustainability, and potentials for 
integrated AFVCs using four country cases: the People’s Republic of China and India, because 
of their expansive wealth of AFVC experiences; these will provide relevant insights to low-
income DMCs, Bangladesh (ADF-blend DMC) and Cambodia (ADF-only DMC).9 A strategic 
evidence-informed policy report for inclusive and sustainable AFVC financing will be produced 
                                                
9  The People’s Republic of China and India were selected due to the variety of good practices on AFVC financing for 
smallholder farms and SMAEs that are in transitional and modern AFVCs phases. Examining their experiences will 
benefit low income DMCs especially in terms of the policy environment that facilitates AFVC financing. Bangladesh 
and  Cambodia  were  also  selected  as  these  are  low-income  DMCs  with  prevalent  traditional  AFVCs.  The 
constraints to AFVC financing in these countries will be assessed, and experiences from the first two countries will 
be evaluated in identifying the drivers for inclusive and sustainable AFVC transformations.

4   
and disseminated in Bangladesh and Cambodia. A communications strategy will be done for 
advocating reforms in key regional forums.  
 
11.  For output 2, the methodology will be a combination of focus group discussions and pilot 
testing. An assessment of commercial banks and other potential financial intermediaries of 
AFVCs will be conducted and an issues paper on market gaps for private sector financing of 
AFVCs  will  be  developed.  Focus  group  discussions  with  national  and  multinational 
agribusinesses,  retailers,  wholesalers,  banks,  microfinance  institutions,  nongovernment 
organizations, and other financial intermediaries will be held to discuss the issues paper and to 
prioritize the issues, challenges, and opportunities for AFVC financing for smallholders and 
SMAEs. On the basis of the selected issues, well-defined criteria, and a competitive selection 
process, there will be a call for proposals for technical support that will facilitate the start-up, 
replication, or scale-up of innovative AFVC financing models for smallholder farms and SMAEs. 
The country focus of the proposals will include, but not be limited to, Bangladesh and Cambodia. 
The implementation of at least three to six of the best proposals will be closely monitored and 
periodically evaluated. The proposals that have not been selected but merit dissemination will 
also be published through a compendium of business case studies.   
 
12.  For output 3, a review and assessment will be done of available knowledge platforms on 
AFVCs in Asia and the clients these serve. Information gaps and priority issues will be identified 
to explore possibilities for collaboration on knowledge platforms. A knowledge platform for 
innovative AFVC financing of smallholder farms and SMAEs will be set up in Bangladesh and 
Cambodia.  
 
13.  The TA will culminate in a regional conference that will present the findings of the TA, 
and develop networks for the continued dissemination and utilization of its findings.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing     
 
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1,500,000 equivalent to be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). Appendix 2 lists the cost items 
for the proposed TA. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The TA will be implemented for about 24 months, from January 2012 to December 2013. 
ADB, through its Regional and Sustainable Development Department, will be the executing 
agency, and will be responsible for the overall supervision of the TA to ensure the timely 
delivery of quality outputs, and the attainment of the outcome and impact. It will work closely 
with the communities of practice on agriculture, rural development, and food security, and 
financial sector development, as well as the ADB regional departments and the Private Sector 
Operations Department to ensure coordinated action on the policy measures and the application 
of the innovative and scalable financing of value chain models.  
 
16.  For outputs 1 and 3, the TA will require the services of 16 person-months of international 
experts and 24 person-months of national experts in the fields of food chain policies, food value 
chains, agribusiness finance, knowledge management, and information and communication. 
The terms of reference for the consultants are outlined in Appendix 3. The consultants will be 
selected and engaged through a firm. The recruitment of consultants will be done through 
quality- and cost-based selection with a quality–cost ratio of 90:10 to ensure that the stacked 
survey methodology and case studies are rigorously done. The firms will submit simplified

5 
technical proposals. The consultants will be engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on 
the  Use  of  Consultants  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  The  TA  proceeds  will  be 
disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
amended from time to time). The selected consulting firm will hold an inception workshop within 
2 months of the TA’s approval to provide a detailed work plan and milestones for each output. 
The firm will submit the following reports to ADB: (i) an inception report, (ii) a midterm report, (iii) 
a final report, (iv) semiannual financial statements, and (v) an audited annual financial statement. 
The firm will also produce a book that provides the findings of the survey, case studies, and the 
strategic policy and institutional reform agenda. Before starting proposed activities within a DMC, 
receipt of no-objection letters from the governments of Bangladesh, Cambodia, the People’s 
Republic of China, and India will be required. 
 
17.  For output 2, the TA will require the services of 13 person-months of international 
experts and 19 person-months of national experts. Expertise in the following areas will be 
accessed:  an  agribusiness  finance  specialist,  a  participatory  multi-stakeholder  facilitator,  a 
conference event coordinator, and an editor (Appendix 3 contains the terms of reference). An 
unallocated 2 person-months of international expert services are set aside in anticipation of 
other expert needs on AFVC financing and development for the pilot-testing activities such as 
finance management, legal services, food packaging and labeling, and a risk insurance expert. 
These expert needs will be determined during the selection of proposals for technical support. 
ADB will recruit the consultants on an individual basis. Recruitment of individual consultants will 
be in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants.  
 
18.  A steering committee will be established, comprising staff from ADB’s Regional and 
Sustainable Development Department, Private Sector Operations Department, and regional 
operations departments to oversee the conduct of the activities for output 2. Private sector and 
nongovernment organization representatives may be invited as resource persons to provide 
feedback on the call for pilot-testing proposals and the selection process. The pilot-testing 
activities may include proposals for the purchase of computers; and small equipment for farm 
production, postharvest, processing, storage, assembling, and packing. There may also be the 
need for the conduct of small market and feasibility studies, training and capacity development, 
access to social networks, development of tool kits, study tours, and access to advisory services. 
Procurement of goods and related services for the pilot-testing proposals will be in accordance 
with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). Disbursements will 
be undertaken in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook.  
  
19.  The expected outputs of the TA will be disseminated through the regional conference, 
the knowledge platform, and development networks. A book will be produced and disseminated, 
containing the results of the country cases and the compendium of innovative AFVC financing 
models. These  will  also  be  presented  in  strategic forums  and  development  websites. The 
publication of the book and compendium will be contracted by ADB’s Department of External 
Relations.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis
for Innovative Financing for Agriculture and Food Value Chains, and hereby reports this action 
to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will require a total of 29 person-months of international 
and 43 person-months of national consulting services. Recruitment of consultants for outputs 1 
and 3 will be done through a firm that will be selected on a quality- and cost-based process. The 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  will  recruit  the  experts  for  output  3  on  an  individual 
engagement basis. The recruitment process will be in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The specialist requirements are 
discussed below.  
 
A.  Consultant Requirements for Outputs 1 and 3 
 
2.  Food value chain policy specialist and team leader (international, 7 person-months). 
The expert should have a graduate degree in agriculture economics or development economics 
with at least 10 years of demonstrated knowledge and experience in agriculture value chain 
development and policy analysis in Asia. The outputs will be (i) four evidence-based country 
case studies with a strategic policy and institutional reform agenda; (ii)  a communications 
strategy for dissemination and identification of champions who will engage in strategic forums; 
and (iii) a publishable report on agriculture food value chains (AFVCs) financing, policy and 
institutional challenges, and opportunities. Responsibilities will include the following:  
 
(i)  lead in the design of the conceptual framework that links the supply–demand 
analysis of AFVC financing with the policy and institutional measures for inclusive 
and sustainable AFVC financing;  
(ii)  supervise and coordinate the study teams that will conduct the multi-stacked 
survey and structured interviews in the four countries;  
(iii)  lead in the policy analysis, and coordinate and supervise the write-up of the 
reports, and development of the reports into a publishable book; and  
(iv)  supervise  the  presentation  and  dissemination  of  the  findings  in  appropriate 
forums, including the regional conference.  
 
3.  Food value chain expert (international, 4 person-months). The expert should have a 
graduate degree in agriculture economics or economics with at least 8 years of professional 
work experience in value chain development in Asia. He or she will be responsible for the 
stacked survey and case studies and will 
 
(i)  lead in the design of the multi-stacked survey and work directly with the national 
experts in the timely conduct of the surveys and structured interviews, collation, 
consolidation, and analysis of the survey results;  
(ii)  together with the team leader, contribute in the case studies and draft the report; 
and  
(iii)  participate in the presentation and dissemination of results in key forums.  
 
4.  Agribusiness  value  chain  financing  expert  (international,  2  person-months).  The 
expert should have a graduate degree in finance or related fields with demonstrated experience 
in value chain financing in Asia. The outputs will be (i) articulation of the key policy, institutional, 
and regulatory constraints and priority recommendations in AFVC financing for smallholder 
farms and small and medium-sized agro-enterprises (SMAEs); and (ii) a report on AFVC-related 
funds and recommendations. He or she will

Appendix 3  11 
(i)   contribute to the policy analysis on AFVC financing;  
(ii)  provide recommendations and lessons learned that will facilitate the access to 
AFVC financing of smallholder farms and SMAEs; and  
(iii)  conduct  market  mapping  of  AFVC-related  funds,  AFVC  funds,  and  AFVC 
financing models of development partners and those being provided by private 
commercial banks, and assess which of these ADB could do differently.  
 
5.  Agriculture and food value chain experts (6 national, 20 person-months). He or she 
should have a university degree in agriculture economics, development economics, or finance 
with at least 3 years of work experience in value chain development. Deliverables are stacked 
surveys and case studies at country levels. He or she will  
 
(i)  conduct the multi-stacked surveys and structured interviews at the country level;  
(ii)  lead in the collation and consolidation of information;  
(iii)  provide inputs to the comprehensive review of the value chain development in 
the country sites, and the value chain financing;  
(iv)  contribute in developing the typology matrix for the supply and demand models of 
AFVC financing; and 
(v)  provide inputs in the analysis, and assist in the production, of the reports.  
 
6.  Knowledge management expert (international, 3 person-months). He or she should 
have at least 6 years of experience in knowledge management and communication as well as 
work experience in Bangladesh and/or Cambodia. Deliverables are (i) knowledge platforms in 
Bangladesh and Cambodia are operational; and (ii) a scoping study of available knowledge 
platforms that may be suitable for collaboration among providers to serve developing member 
countries (DMCs). He or she will 
 
(i)  review and assess available knowledge platforms in Asia and the clients these 
serve; 
(ii)  identify  the  information  gaps  and  priority  issues  for  knowledge  management 
platforms for Bangladesh and Cambodia; 
(iii)  together with the information technology expert, set up the most appropriate 
knowledge platform for Bangladesh and Cambodia; and  
(iv)  produce the scoping report  
 
7.  Information and communication technology expert (national, 4 person-months). He 
or she should have a university degree in computer science, or other relevant degrees, and at 
least 5 years of experience in website development. The deliverable will be the technical set-up 
of the knowledge platform. In coordination with the knowledge management expert, he or she 
will  
 
(i)  develop a knowledge platform for Bangladesh and Cambodia; and 
(ii)  provide suggestions for sustaining the platform.  
 
B.  Consultant Requirements for Output 2  
 
8.  Agribusiness finance specialists (international, 9 person-months; national, 11 person-
months). He or she should have a graduate degree in finance economics or agribusiness, with 
vast  work  experience  in  networks  with  private  sector-run  AFVC  value  chain  financing  for 
smallholder farms and SMAEs in developing Asia. The outputs will be (i) an issues paper 
scoping the bottlenecks for agribusinesses, banks, and other financial intermediaries in AFVC

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
financing to smallholder farms and SMAEs in low-income DMCs; (ii) mechanisms for the call for 
technical  support  proposals;  (iii)  successful  implementation  of  the  selection  process; 
(iv) progress  reports  on  pilot  activities  and  assessments  of  their  performance;  and  (v) a 
compendium of innovative business case models  linking SMAEs and smallholder farms to 
AFVC finance and markets. Specific tasks will be to 
 
(i)  draft the issues paper and together with the participatory expert, conduct and 
oversee the focus group discussions; 
(ii)  establish the steering committee and provide inputs to the criteria and selection 
process as well as the mechanisms for the call for technical support proposals;  
(iii)  prepare the prioritized issues papers for discussion by the steering committee; 
(iv)  oversee the competitive call for proposals and the selection of about three to six 
of the best proposals for pilot testing, and oversee their implementation and 
monitoring; and 
(v)  of those not selected, develop the compendium of innovative financing business 
case models. 
  
9.  Participatory  multi-stakeholder  facilitator  expert  (international,  2  person-months; 
national, 2 person-months): He or she should have a graduate degree in social sciences or 
related fields, and demonstrated 5 years experience in the design, development, and conduct of 
participatory multi-stakeholder dialogues and consultations. The expert should also have vast 
experience in the use of social networks for the conduct of focus group discussions involving 
private and civil society sectors. The outputs are (i) successful focus group discussions with a 
wide outreach, and (ii) report on the findings of focus group discussions and consultations for 
identifying  the  priority  themes for the  pilot  testing  activities.  Specific tasks  will  include  the 
following:   
 
(i)  review the profile of prospective stakeholders, develop a profile directory, and 
identify the criteria for selection of stakeholders and country focus;  
(ii)  together  with  the  agribusiness  finance  expert,  develop  the  design  of  the 
stakeholder  dialogues,  and  modality  for  consultations,  and  implement  the 
consultations; and  
(iii)  prepare a report of findings from consultations, and provide recommendations for 
priority focal themes, country focus, and mechanism for the call of proposals.  
 
10.  Conference event coordinator (national, 2 person-months). He or she should have at 
least 8 years of experience in the organization and coordination of large events/workshops and 
possess basic management skills necessary to organize and coordinate such events/workshops 
successfully. The output will be a successful conference. He or she will  
 
(i)   design and develop the forum content and program;  
(ii)   take charge of the logistics preparations, communication strategies, and other 
forum related matters; and  
(iii)   seek partners for the conduct of the forum.  
  
11.  Editor  (national,  4  person-months):  He  or  she  should  have  a  graduate  degree  in 
development journalism with at least 10 years of work experience in manuscript and copy 
editing work on development related topics. He or she should have at least three published 
edited documents. The outputs will be edited documents from the TA. He or she will

Appendix 3  13 
(i)  edit the reports of the TA;  
(ii)  work on the typeset and copyediting needs of the book, compendiums, and 
conference materials; and  
(iii)  develop communication pieces for dissemination of the TA’s reports and findings.  
 
12.  Unallocated  experts  and resource  persons  (international, 2 person-months).  The 
expertise  requirements  for  the  potential  pilot  food  value  chain  innovation  solutions  will  be 
determined only during the selection of the activities for pilot testing. Expertise needs may be in 
the  areas  of  agribusiness  finance  management,  food  value  chain  logistics  management, 
marketing strategy, consumer awareness, food packaging, contract development, and waste 
management for inefficiency reduction, risk insurance schemes, and commodities exchange.
